docs.title: Welcome to DevLang — Programming in Hindi for Everyone!
docs.text:
DevLang is a JavaScript-based programming language that brings the warmth and familiarity of Hindi keywords to the world of coding. Imagine writing programs where bolo prints your messages, agar checks conditions, and jabtak creates loops — making programming feel more natural and intuitive for Hindi speakers and language enthusiasts alike.

Built as an interpreted language for beginners and experienced developers, DevLang bridges the gap between natural language and code. It's designed to make programming accessible, educational, and enjoyable by letting you think and code in a language that feels closer to home.

Whether you're learning your first programming concepts, teaching others, or simply exploring how languages can be more inclusive, DevLang offers a unique and welcoming approach to coding. Every keyword carries the spirit of making technology accessible to everyone, regardless of their native tongue.

Join our growing community of developers who believe that programming should speak everyone's language. Let's make coding as inclusive as the languages we speak every day!

docs.title: Language-Inclusive
docs.text: Program using Hindi-inspired keywords that make code more intuitive and accessible to Hindi speakers and learners.

docs.title: Beginner-Friendly
docs.text: Perfect for learning programming concepts without the barrier of English-only syntax. Great for schools, colleges, and self-learners.

docs.title: Simple & Powerful
docs.text: Easy-to-understand syntax with familiar keywords, yet capable of expressing complex programming logic.

docs.title: JavaScript-Based
docs.text: Built on JavaScript, runs on Node.js, and leverages the robust ecosystem of web technologies.

docs.title: Open Source
docs.text:
Completely free and open source. Contribute, customize, and make it your own!

Excellent tool for understanding how programming languages work — from tokenization to interpretation.

docs.title: Hello World in DevLang
docs.text: bolo "Namaste Duniya!"

docs.title: Variables and Math
docs.text:
x = 10
y = 20
sum = x + y
bolo sum

docs.title: Conditions
docs.text:
age = 18
agar age >= 18
  bolo "You can vote"
nhi_toh
  bolo "Too young to vote"

docs.title: Loops
docs.text:
i = 1
jabtak i <= 5
  bolo i
  i = i + 1

docs.title: Core Features
docs.text:
• Hindi Keywords: bolo, agar, nhi_toh, jabtak, and more
  • Variables: Store and manipulate data easily
  • Conditionals: Make decisions with agar and nhi_toh
  • Loops: Repeat actions with jabtak
  • Arithmetic Operations: Addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, modulo
  • Comparison Operators: >, <, >=, <=, ==, !=
  • CLI Interface: Run files or execute code inline
  • No Dependencies: Just Node.js required

docs.title: What Makes DevLang Special?
docs.text:
DevLang isn't just another programming language — it's a statement about inclusivity in technology. By using Hindi keywords, it:

  • Reduces Language Barriers: Helps non-English speakers learn programming in a more comfortable environment
  • Promotes Cultural Diversity: Shows that programming languages can embrace different linguistic backgrounds
  • Educational Value: Teaches both programming concepts and language design principles
  • Community Building: Brings together developers interested in making tech more accessible

docs.title: Get Started
docs.text:
Ready to start coding in Hindi? Check out our comprehensive documentation:

  • Installation — Get DevLang up and running in minutes
  • CLI Usage — Learn how to run DevLang programs
  • Language Syntax — Master DevLang's syntax and structure
  • Keywords Reference — Complete list of all Hindi keywords
  • Examples — Practical code examples to learn from
  • Internals — Understand how DevLang works under the hood
  • Contributing — Join the community and contribute
  • FAQ — Common questions answered

docs.title: Community & Support
docs.text:
DevLang is open source and welcomes contributions from everyone! Whether you want to:

  • Add new features or keywords
  • Improve documentation
  • Fix bugs
  • Share your DevLang programs
  • Suggest improvements

Visit our GitHub repository and join the community!

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text:
"Programming should speak everyone's language, not just English."

DevLang is built on the belief that technology should be accessible to everyone, regardless of the language they speak. By making programming more inclusive through localized keywords, we hope to inspire the next generation of developers who might have been held back by language barriers.

Let's code in a language that feels like home! 🚀

docs.title: CLI Usage
docs.text:
Run a DevLang file:

node devlang.js -f program.dev

Run inline code:

node devlang.js -e "bolo 'Hello'"

Flags:

  • -f : Run a file
  • -e : Execute inline code

docs.title: Contributing to DevLang
docs.text:
Thank you for your interest in improving DevLang! We welcome contributions from everyone, whether you are fixing typos, clarifying explanations, adding new features, or improving the language itself.

Here's how you can help:

docs.title: 1. Documentation
docs.text:
All documentation files are Markdown (.md) files located inside the /docs folder in the repository.

  • Edit relevant .md files to improve clarity
  • Add examples to help users understand features better
  • Fix typos, grammar, or outdated information
  • Create tutorials or guides for specific use cases

docs.title: 2. Code Contributions
docs.text:
• Add new keywords or language features
  • Improve the tokenizer, parser, or interpreter
  • Fix bugs or optimize performance
  • Write tests for existing functionality
  • Add support for new operators or data types

docs.title: 3. Examples and Sample Programs
docs.text:
• Create interesting example programs in DevLang
  • Add practical use cases that demonstrate language features
  • Write sample projects that showcase DevLang's capabilities

docs.title: Fork and Clone
docs.text:
1. Fork the DevLang repository to your own GitHub account
  2. Clone your fork locally:
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/DevLang.git
cd DevLang
  1. Create a new branch for your changes:
git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

docs.title: For Code Changes
docs.text:
1. Make your modifications to the relevant files:
  2. tokenizer.js - Lexical analysis
  3. parser.js - Syntax analysis and AST generation
  4. interpreter.js - Code execution
  5. tokenTypes.js - Token definitions

  6. Other supporting files as needed

  7. Test your changes thoroughly:

node devlang.js -f test_program.dev
  1. Ensure your code follows clean coding practices

docs.title: For Documentation Changes
docs.text:
1. Edit the Markdown files in the /docs folder
  2. Preview your changes locally (see below)

docs.title: Previewing Documentation Locally
docs.text:
Before submitting your changes, preview how the documentation will look:

  1. Install MkDocs and Material theme (if not already installed):
pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material
  1. From the project root directory, run:
mkdocs serve
  1. Open your browser at http://127.0.0.1:8000/ to see a live preview

When you save your Markdown files, the preview will update automatically.

docs.title: Submitting Changes
docs.text:
1. Commit your changes with clear, descriptive messages:
git add .
git commit -m "Add feature: description of what you changed"
  1. Push your branch to your fork:
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

  1. Open a Pull Request (PR) from your branch to the original repository's main branch

  2. In your PR description:

  3. Explain what changes you made and why
  4. Reference any related issues
  5. Include screenshots if applicable (for documentation changes)

We review all pull requests promptly and provide feedback if necessary.

docs.title: Reporting Issues or Suggesting Features
docs.text:
If you find bugs, have questions, or want to suggest new features:

  1. Check if the issue already exists in the GitHub Issues
  2. If not, open a new issue with:
  3. A clear, descriptive title
  4. Detailed description of the problem or suggestion
  5. Steps to reproduce (for bugs)
  6. Expected vs actual behavior
  7. Your environment (Node.js version, OS, etc.)

docs.title: Code Style Guidelines
docs.text:
• Use meaningful variable and function names
  • Add comments to explain complex logic
  • Keep functions small and focused
  • Follow existing code patterns in the project
  • Test your changes before submitting

docs.title: Adding New Keywords
docs.text:
If you want to add a new Hindi keyword:

  1. Add the token type in tokenTypes.js
  2. Update the tokenizer in tokenizer.js to recognize it
  3. Update the parser in parser.js to handle its syntax
  4. Update the interpreter in interpreter.js to execute it
  5. Add documentation and examples
  6. Update the keywords reference in docs/keywords.md

docs.title: Our Commitment
docs.text:
We believe in open and collaborative development to make programming more accessible through Hindi keywords. Your feedback and contributions make this project better for the whole community!

Thank you for being part of the DevLang community!

Happy coding! 🚀

docs.title: Hello World
docs.text: bolo "Hello DevLang"

docs.title: Simple Loop
docs.text:
i = 1
jabtak i <= 5
  bolo i
  i = i + 1

docs.title: Variables and Arithmetic
docs.text:
x = 10
y = 20
sum = x + y
bolo "Sum is: "
bolo sum

docs.title: Conditional Statements
docs.text:
age = 18
agar age >= 18
  bolo "You can vote"
nhi_toh
  bolo "You cannot vote yet"

docs.title: Nested Conditions
docs.text:
marks = 85
agar marks >= 90
  bolo "Grade: A+"
nhi_toh
  agar marks >= 75
    bolo "Grade: A"
  nhi_toh
    bolo "Grade: B"

docs.title: Countdown Timer
docs.text:
count = 10
jabtak count > 0
  bolo count
  count = count - 1
bolo "Blast off!"

docs.title: Even Number Checker
docs.text:
num = 1
jabtak num <= 10
  remainder = num % 2
  agar remainder == 0
    bolo num
  num = num + 1

docs.title: Multiplication Table
docs.text:
num = 5
i = 1
bolo "Multiplication table of 5:"
jabtak i <= 10
  result = num * i
  bolo result
  i = i + 1

docs.title: Sum of First N Numbers
docs.text:
n = 10
sum = 0
i = 1
jabtak i <= n
  sum = sum + i
  i = i + 1
bolo "Sum is: "
bolo sum

docs.title: Simple Calculator
docs.text:
a = 15
b = 3
bolo "Addition: "
bolo a + b
bolo "Subtraction: "
bolo a - b
bolo "Multiplication: "
bolo a * b
bolo "Division: "
bolo a / b

docs.title: Factorial Calculator
docs.text:
n = 5
factorial = 1
i = 1
jabtak i <= n
  factorial = factorial * i
  i = i + 1
bolo "Factorial is: "
bolo factorial

docs.title: What file extension do DevLang programs use?
docs.text: DevLang source code files use the .dev extension.

docs.title: How do I run a DevLang program?
docs.text:
After installing DevLang, run:

node devlang.js -f your_program.dev

You can also execute inline code with the -e option:

node devlang.js -e "bolo 'Hello World'"

For more installation options, see the Installation Guide.

docs.title: What are the Hindi keywords used in DevLang?
docs.text:
DevLang uses Hindi-inspired keywords to make programming more accessible:

  • bolo — Print output (like print or console.log)
  • agar — If condition
  • nhi_toh — Else condition
  • jabtak — While loop
  • puchoo — Take input (planned feature)

See the Keywords Reference for a complete list.

docs.title: What data types does DevLang support?
docs.text:
Currently, DevLang supports:

  • Numbers (integers and decimals)
  • Strings (text enclosed in quotes)
  • Variables (dynamically typed)

Additional data types like arrays and objects are planned for future releases.

docs.title: Are functions supported in DevLang?
docs.text: Not yet. DevLang currently focuses on basic programming constructs like variables, conditionals, and loops. User-defined functions are a planned feature for future versions.

docs.title: How does DevLang handle errors?
docs.text:
DevLang provides error messages for:

  • Syntax errors — When code doesn't follow the language syntax
  • Runtime errors — When errors occur during execution
  • Semantic errors — When code is syntactically correct but logically invalid

Error handling is continuously being improved to provide better debugging information.

docs.title: Can I use DevLang for real projects?
docs.text:
DevLang is currently an educational and experimental language. It's perfect for:

  • Learning programming concepts
  • Teaching coding to Hindi speakers
  • Exploring language design
  • Experimenting with localized programming

It's not recommended for production use at this stage.

docs.title: What Node.js version does DevLang require?
docs.text: DevLang requires Node.js version 12.0.0 or higher. It's recommended to use the latest LTS version for best compatibility.

docs.title: Can I add new keywords to DevLang?
docs.text:
Absolutely! DevLang is open source and designed to be extensible. To add new keywords:

  1. Define the token type in tokenTypes.js
  2. Update the tokenizer in tokenizer.js
  3. Modify the parser in parser.js
  4. Update the interpreter in interpreter.js
  5. Add documentation and examples

See the Contributing Guide for detailed instructions.

docs.title: How does DevLang compare to other programming languages?
docs.text:
DevLang is unique because:

  • Language Inclusivity — Uses Hindi keywords instead of English
  • Educational Focus — Designed for learning, not production
  • Simplicity — Minimal syntax and easy to understand
  • Open Source — Completely free and customizable
  • JavaScript-based — Runs on Node.js without additional dependencies

docs.title: Can I contribute to DevLang?
docs.text:
Yes! Contributions are welcome from users of all experience levels. You can:

  • Add new features or keywords
  • Improve the interpreter, parser, or tokenizer
  • Enhance documentation
  • Fix bugs
  • Create example programs
  • Suggest improvements

See the Contributing Guide for details on submitting pull requests and reporting issues.

docs.title: Where can I find more documentation?
docs.text:
Full documentation and usage examples are available at:

  • Home — Overview and introduction
  • Installation — Setup instructions
  • CLI Usage — Command-line interface
  • Syntax — Language syntax guide
  • Keywords — Complete keyword reference
  • Examples — Code examples and tutorials
  • Internals — How DevLang works under the hood

docs.title: Is DevLang inspired by other projects?
docs.text: Yes! DevLang is conceptually inspired by projects like Doglang and other educational programming languages, but it's independently implemented with its own unique focus on Hindi-based programming and language accessibility.

docs.title: Who created DevLang?
docs.text: DevLang is an open-source project created to promote inclusive programming by making code more accessible to Hindi speakers and demonstrating that programming languages can embrace linguistic diversity.

docs.title: How can I report bugs or request features?
docs.text:
If you find bugs or have feature suggestions:

  1. Check the GitHub Issues to see if it's already reported
  2. If not, open a new issue with:
  3. Clear description of the bug or feature
  4. Steps to reproduce (for bugs)
  5. Expected behavior
  6. Your environment details

docs.title: Can I use DevLang to teach programming?
docs.text:
Absolutely! DevLang is perfect for educational settings, especially:

  • Teaching programming to Hindi-speaking students
  • Introducing coding concepts without English language barriers
  • Computer science classes in schools and colleges
  • Self-learners exploring programming
  • Workshops on language design and interpreters

docs.title: What's the future roadmap for DevLang?
docs.text:
Planned features include:

  • User-defined functions
  • Arrays and data structures
  • More operators and built-in functions
  • Better error messages
  • Standard library
  • REPL (interactive mode)
  • More Hindi keywords
  • Input/output operations

If you have other questions, feel free to open an issue on the GitHub repository or contribute to the documentation!

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • Node.js (v12 or later)

docs.title: Clone Repository
docs.text:
Clone the repository:

git clone https://github.com/dev0jha/DevLang.git
cd DevLang

docs.title: Run DevLang
docs.text:
Run DevLang programs directly:

node devlang.js -f program.dev

Or execute inline code:

node devlang.js -e "bolo 'Hello World'"

docs.title: Internals — How DevLang Works
docs.text: This document provides a deep dive into the architecture and implementation details of DevLang. Understanding these internals will help you contribute to the project or build your own programming language.

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
DevLang follows the classic interpreter architecture with three main stages:

Source Code → Tokenizer → Parser → Interpreter → Output
  (.dev)       (Tokens)    (AST)    (Execution)

docs.title: Processing Pipeline
docs.text:
1. Lexical Analysis — Tokenizer converts source code into tokens
  2. Syntactic Analysis — Parser builds an Abstract Syntax Tree (AST)
  3. Execution — Interpreter traverses the AST and executes instructions

docs.title: Stage 1: Tokenizer (Lexical Analysis)
docs.text: File: tokenizer.js

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: The tokenizer (or lexer) performs lexical analysis — breaking down source code into meaningful units called tokens.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
// Input: "bolo 'Hello'"
// Output: [
//   Token(KEYWORD, "bolo"),
//   Token(STRING_LITERAL, "Hello")
// ]

docs.title: Token Types
docs.text:
The tokenizer recognizes several types of tokens:

Token Type Examples Description KEYWORD bolo, agar, jabtak Hindi language keywords IDENTIFIER x, age, counter Variable names INTEGER_LITERAL 42, 100 Numeric values STRING_LITERAL "Hello", "Namaste" Text in quotes ARITHMETIC_OP +, -, *, /, % Math operators COMPARISON_OP >, <, ==, != Comparison operators LOGICAL_OP &&, \|\|, ! Logical operators ASSIGNMENT_OP = Variable assignment LPAREN, RPAREN (, ) Parentheses LBRACE, RBRACE {, } Curly braces

docs.title: Tokenization Process
docs.text:
1. Pattern Matching — Uses regex to identify token patterns
  2. Classification — Determines the type of each token
  3. Token Creation — Creates Token objects with type and value
  4. Stream Building — Produces a sequential list of tokens

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• String Handling — Properly parses quoted strings with escape sequences
  • Keyword Recognition — Identifies Hindi keywords (bolo, agar, etc.)
  • Operator Detection — Recognizes multi-character operators (==, >=, etc.)
  • Whitespace Handling — Automatically skips spaces and newlines

docs.title: Stage 2: Parser (Syntactic Analysis)
docs.text: File: parser.js

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: The parser performs syntactic analysis — building a hierarchical tree structure (AST) that represents the program's logical structure.

docs.title: Abstract Syntax Tree (AST)
docs.text:
An AST represents the grammatical structure of code in tree form:

Program
├── AssignmentStatement
│   ├── Identifier: "x"
│   └── IntegerLiteral: 10
└── PrintStatement
    └── Identifier: "x"

docs.title: Parsing Methods
docs.text:
The parser uses recursive descent parsing with methods for each grammar rule:

  • program() — Top-level program structure
  • statement() — Individual statements
  • expression() — Expressions and values
  • condition() — Conditional expressions
  • loop() — Loop constructs

docs.title: Grammar Rules
docs.text:
DevLang follows this simplified grammar:

Program        → Statement*
Statement      → PrintStmt | AssignStmt | IfStmt | LoopStmt
PrintStmt      → 'bolo' Expression
AssignStmt     → Identifier '=' Expression
IfStmt         → 'agar' Condition Statement ('nhi_toh' Statement)?
LoopStmt       → 'jabtak' Condition Statement
Expression     → Term (('+' | '-') Term)*
Term           → Factor (('*' | '/' | '%') Factor)*
Factor         → Number | String | Identifier | '(' Expression ')'
Condition      → Expression ComparisonOp Expression

docs.title: Node Types
docs.text:
The parser creates different AST node types:

  • Program — Root node containing all statements
  • AssignmentStatement — Variable assignment
  • PrintStatement — Output operation
  • IfStatement — Conditional branching
  • LoopStatement — While loops
  • BinaryOperation — Arithmetic/comparison operations
  • Identifier — Variable reference
  • Literal — Integer or string value

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
The parser provides detailed error messages:

  • Syntax Errors — Missing tokens, unexpected symbols
  • Structure Errors — Malformed statements
  • Position Tracking — Shows where errors occur

docs.title: Stage 3: Interpreter (Execution)
docs.text: File: interpreter.js

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: The interpreter executes the AST by traversing nodes and performing operations.

docs.title: Execution Model
docs.text:
DevLang uses a tree-walking interpreter:

  1. Traverses the AST depth-first
  2. Evaluates each node based on its type
  3. Maintains runtime state in a symbol table
  4. Performs operations and produces output

docs.title: Symbol Table
docs.text:
File: symbolTable.js

The symbol table manages variable storage:

symbolTable = {
  'x': 10,
  'name': 'DevLang',
  'counter': 5
}
  • Variable Storage — Stores identifier-value pairs
  • Scope Management — Handles variable lookups
  • Type Flexibility — Supports dynamic typing

docs.title: Visitor Pattern
docs.text:
The interpreter uses the visitor pattern to handle different node types:

visit(node) {
  switch(node.type) {
    case 'Program': return this.visitProgram(node);
    case 'PrintStatement': return this.visitPrint(node);
    case 'AssignmentStatement': return this.visitAssignment(node);
    // ... more node types
  }
}

docs.title: Print Statement (bolo)
docs.text:
1. Evaluates the expression
  2. Converts to string
  3. Outputs to console

docs.title: Assignment Statement
docs.text:
1. Evaluates right-hand expression
  2. Stores value in symbol table
  3. Associates with identifier

docs.title: Conditional Statement (agar/nhi_toh)
docs.text:
1. Evaluates condition
  2. If true, executes first branch
  3. If false, executes else branch (if present)

docs.title: Loop Statement (jabtak)
docs.text:
1. Evaluates condition
  2. While true, executes body
  3. Re-evaluates condition
  4. Repeats until false

docs.title: Expression Evaluation
docs.text:
The interpreter evaluates expressions recursively:

  • Binary Operations — Performs arithmetic/comparison
  • Variable Lookup — Retrieves values from symbol table
  • Literals — Returns constant values
  • Nested Expressions — Evaluates from innermost to outer

docs.title: Type Coercion
docs.text:
DevLang performs automatic type conversion:

  • String + Number → Concatenation
  • Comparisons → Type-aware comparison
  • Arithmetic → Numeric operations

docs.title: tokenizer.js
docs.text:
• Class: Tokenizer
  • Main Method: tokenize()
  • Output: Array of Token objects
  • Dependencies: tokenTypes.js, token.js

docs.title: parser.js
docs.text:
• Class: Parser
  • Main Method: parse()
  • Output: AST root node
  • Dependencies: tokenTypes.js, astNode.js

docs.title: interpreter.js
docs.text:
• Class: Interpreter
  • Main Methods: execute(), visit()
  • Output: Program execution and side effects
  • Dependencies: All core files

docs.title: Supporting Files
docs.text:
• tokenTypes.js — Token type constants
  • token.js — Token class definition
  • astNode.js — AST node class
  • symbolTable.js — Variable storage
  • devlang.js — CLI entry point

docs.title: Execution Flow Example
docs.text:
Let's trace how this code executes:

x = 10
bolo x

docs.title: 1. Tokenization
docs.text:
[
  Token(IDENTIFIER, "x"),
  Token(ASSIGNMENT_OP, "="),
  Token(INTEGER_LITERAL, "10"),
  Token(KEYWORD, "bolo"),
  Token(IDENTIFIER, "x")
]

docs.title: 2. Parsing
docs.text:
Program
├── AssignmentStatement
│   ├── Identifier: "x"
│   └── IntegerLiteral: 10
└── PrintStatement
    └── Identifier: "x"

docs.title: 3. Execution
docs.text:
1. Visit Program node → Process children
  2. Visit AssignmentStatement
  3. Evaluate right side: 10
  4. Store in symbol table: symbolTable['x'] = 10
  5. Visit PrintStatement
  6. Evaluate expression: lookup x → 10
  7. Output: 10

Result: Prints 10 to console

docs.title: Lexical Errors
docs.text: Caught during tokenization: - Invalid characters - Malformed strings

docs.title: Syntax Errors
docs.text: Caught during parsing: - Missing tokens - Invalid grammar - Unexpected symbols

docs.title: Runtime Errors
docs.text: Caught during execution: - Undefined variables - Type errors - Division by zero

docs.title: 1. Simplicity
docs.text: DevLang prioritizes simplicity over performance: - Clear, readable code - Straightforward algorithms - Easy to understand and modify

docs.title: 2. Educational Focus
docs.text: Designed for learning: - Well-documented code - Standard patterns (visitor, recursive descent) - Modular architecture

docs.title: 3. Extensibility
docs.text: Easy to extend: - Add new keywords in tokenizer - Add new grammar rules in parser - Add new operations in interpreter

docs.title: 4. Language Inclusivity
docs.text: Hindi keywords make programming accessible: - Familiar vocabulary - Cultural relevance - Lower language barriers

docs.title: Current Implementation
docs.text:
• Interpreter Speed — Not optimized for performance
  • Memory Usage — Creates full AST in memory
  • Execution Model — Tree-walking (slower than bytecode)

docs.title: Potential Optimizations
docs.text:
Future improvements could include:

  1. Bytecode Compilation — Convert AST to bytecode
  2. JIT Compilation — Compile hot paths at runtime
  3. Symbol Table Optimization — Use hash maps
  4. Constant Folding — Evaluate constants at parse time
  5. Tail Call Optimization — For recursive functions

docs.title: Planned Features
docs.text:
1. Functions — User-defined functions with parameters
  2. Arrays — List data structure
  3. Objects — Key-value data structures
  4. Modules — Import/export system
  5. Standard Library — Built-in functions
  6. REPL — Interactive mode
  7. Debugging — Breakpoints and inspection

docs.title: Language Extensions
docs.text:
• More Hindi keywords
  • Enhanced string operations
  • File I/O operations
  • Error handling (try/catch)
  • Classes and objects

docs.title: Contributing to Internals
docs.text:
If you want to modify DevLang internals:

  1. Understand the Pipeline — Know how each stage works
  2. Maintain Separation — Keep tokenizer, parser, and interpreter separate
  3. Add Tests — Test new features thoroughly
  4. Document Changes — Update this documentation
  5. Follow Patterns — Use existing code patterns

See Contributing Guide for detailed instructions.

docs.title: References and Learning Resources
docs.text:
• Crafting Interpreters by Robert Nystrom
  • Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools (Dragon Book)
  • Writing An Interpreter In Go by Thorsten Ball
  • Let's Build a Compiler by Jack Crenshaw

Understanding these internals will help you: - Contribute new features - Fix bugs effectively - Build your own programming language - Learn about language implementation

Happy exploring! 🚀

docs.title: Keywords Reference
docs.text: Keyword Description bolo Print output agar If condition nhi_toh Else condition jabtak Loop puchoo Take input

docs.title: Print Statement
docs.text: bolo "Namaste Duniya"

docs.title: Variables
docs.text:
x = 10
bolo x

docs.title: Conditional
docs.text:
agar x > 5
  bolo "Bada hai"
nhi_toh
  bolo "Chota hai"
